awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: U.S. Institutions after COVID-19: Trust, accountability, and public perceptions
awd_abstract_narration:
COVID-19 upended social, economic, and political systems throughout the world. The United States has faced particular challenges due to its heterogeneity and federal nature. The COVID States project is a large-scale data collection that includes over-time data from diverse state-level samples. The project tracks state-level post-pandemic recovery, studying topics such as trust in institutions, information acquisition and impact, accountability, and economic inequality. It also documents how federal and state policies affect the populace when it comes to these topics. Further, the COVID States project provides access to researchers from all backgrounds, types of academic institutions, and career stages through a competition for survey module time and provides a user-friendly website with data trackers for use by researchers, students, journalists, policymakers, and the public.

The COVID States project conducts over-time state-level surveys from all 50 states and D.C. Each survey includes up to 30,000 total respondents, using quota sampling by state. This allows for generalizable inferences at the state and national levels. Post-pandemic data provide an unprecedented opportunity for novel over-time and across-space research designs. The project over-samples demographic minority respondents to facilitate study of heterogeneous social groups. This includes data on trust in political figures and institutions, knowledge and information, political evaluations, behavioral adaptation, physical health, economic well-being, mental health, and more. It also contains detailed social network batteries that allow for the study of inter-household and inter-group transmission of health and information. This is complemented by Twitter data from survey respondents who allow it. This enables the project to identify information sharing and study political discourse.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project produced over 100 public reports addressing all aspects of the COVID-19 pandemic, ranging from mental health to long covid so social, economic, and racial divides in attitudes and behaviors (e.g., social distancing, mask wearing, vaccination, trust in public health officials and agencies, misperceptions regarding the COVID vaccine, etc.). The surveys also provided insights into related social and political developments surrounding the pandemic. It included 29 survey waves, each recruiting participants from all 50 US states plus the District of Columbia, and totalling over 500,000 survey participants. These data will be permanently available to students, researchers and practitioners interested in better understanding how Americans responded to the pandemic and how the US states differed in their attitudes and behaviors. Throughout the pandemic, we consulted with local, state, and federal officials regarding our pandemic-related findings (e.g., determining which strategies were most effective for persuading Americans to be vaccinated; understanding Americans' reasons for resisting vaccination, etc.). Our findings were reported in virtually every major media outlet in the US, and in over 1,000 local news stories around the country. To date, we have published several dozen scholarly articles based on our data and we are currently working on a book on trust, all derived from the project's survey data. We also created a series of informational dashboards for journalists, policymakers and researchers, covering a wide range of information, from COVID-related attitudes and behaviors, to the popularity of US governors, to Americans' trust in a wide range of institutions, organizations, and individuals. The dashboards covered the period April 2020 through 2023. It also facilitated related research from scholars who were invited to submit survey "modules" in order to take advantage of our unique ability to simultaneously survey Americans in all 50 states. Finally, we created a website (www.covidstates.org) where all COVID States products are freely available to the public.
